newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Leading candidates in Chechen presidential vote. [CORRECTED 10:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Leading candidates in Chechen presidential vote. [CORRECTED 10:00 GMT]

text.p: Following are the leading candidates running for president in Monday's election in the breakaway Russian region of Chechnya:

SHAMIL BASAYEV, 32, a national hero in Chechnya, but a figure of hate in Moscow, made his name when he and his guerrilla fighters stormed the southern Russian town of Budennovsk in June 1995, taking more than 1,000 hostages.
The brash act forced Moscow to the negotiating table, but it took another two years for a final peace deal to be agreed.
Basayev's toughness and his promise to stamp out post-war crime has won him many backers, especially among young people. He has advocated public executions for serious crimes.
But some voters fear that electing such a controversial figure would hurt Chechnya's image in the outside world and damage relations with Moscow.
ASLAN MASKHADOV, 45, was chief commander of Chechnya's resistance army during the 21-month war with Russian soldiers sent to crush its independence bid.

He led peace negotiations that culminated in the full Russian withdrawal from Chechnya, leaving it a de facto independent state, although a final decision on its status has been postponed for five years.
Many in the Kremlin leadership see Maskhadov as the most pragmatic and acceptable of major Chechen political figures.
With a modest manner, Maskhadov kept a low profile during the campaign, making only one swing through the tiny republic. He does not have a published political programme.
MOVLADI UDUGOV, 34, is a longshot candidate who rose to fame when he served as information minister during the fighting and broadcast his message from mountain hideouts by satellite telephone.
The wily, slightly built Ududgov often defeated Russia's propaganda machine with his version of events. He was not always accurate, but he repeatedly beat Moscow to the punch.
His presidential campaign, the most professional of any of the candidates, stresses his devotion to "Islamic Order."
His home life echoes his Moslem-oriented politics. He has two wives and is the only major presidential candidate to practice polygamy, as permitted by Moslem custom.

ZELIMKHAN YANDARBIYEV, 45, Chechnya's current leader and one of the region's best-known poets, was vice president to separatist president Dzhokhar Dudayev, but many observers say his chances of winning are slim.
He was one of the first Chechens to oppose Russian control openly, but he was not one of the more visible wartime figures, and this has hurt his current image.
Born in Kazakhstan, where the entire Chechen population was deported in 1944 by Soviet dictator Josef Stalin, he returned to Chechnya with his family after Stalin died.
Yandarbiyev has worked as a mason, assistant shepherd and as an oil-well driller. He has emphasised his adherence to Islamic principles and takes credit for setting up Koran-based Shariat courts.
Nine others (corrects from twelve others) are also contesting the January 27 presidential election, during which Chechen voters will also choose a 63-member parliament.
